stream_context.summary: Kaze finalized mission names and created a music-synced intro cutscene for the 'Oily Boily Bay' level. He then began blocking out a new Wild West-themed level, creating a versatile new 3D model for colored warp pipes and outlining a scavenger hunt mission. Throughout the stream, he discussed his core game design philosophy, team collaboration logistics, and frustrations with community feedback.

development_findings.summary: Kaze's process for creating the 'Oily Boily Bay' intro cutscene was driven entirely by the music, meticulously timing camera cuts to specific beats to create a powerful mood.
development_findings.quote: The most important part of the cutscene for me is that it's fitting to the music. So, which beat do we cut it on? That's the question.

development_findings.summary: The Wild West level is designed with two distinct sections: a traditional town and a more surreal canyon filled with giant, symbolic objects (shotgun, wheel, skull) that function as platforming elements.
development_findings.quote: This next area is gonna be a little more surreal. This area is gonna have mostly just canyons but inside the canyons there's gonna be Wild West references. Just things that are symbolic for it.

development_findings.summary: The project has a hard technical constraint to remain under 64 megabytes to ensure it can run on original N64 hardware with a standard flash cart.
development_findings.quote: Yes, it is one of my conditions that it fits on a normal N64 cartridge. I'm not gonna go above 64 megabytes.

development_findings.summary: Kaze believes original N64 developers over-indexed on lowering poly counts instead of tackling core performance bottlenecks, a mistake he aims to avoid.
development_findings.quote: The people that made N64 games thought if they just made their stuff low-poly it would run better. And they never actually addressed the real issues that they had in their games. So all the N64 games are way too low-poly for their own good.

development_findings.summary: When a crash occurred after implementing new warp pipe models, Kaze used the NEMU64 emulator to find the exact program counter address of the crash and diagnosed the issue in his custom code at the assembly level, showcasing his deep technical expertise.
development_findings.quote: You don't really need debug symbols if you're just really really fucking good at assembling.

development_findings.summary: Kaze developed a system for multi-colored pipes using a single 3D model, dynamically changing its color via a behavior parameter. He adjusted the color palette after considering and testing for colorblind accessibility.
Star and mission names are designed to serve as hints for the player, such as naming a mission 'The Crane and the Cannon' to guide the player's actions.
The game is planned to have 15 courses, the same number as the original Super Mario 64, but Kaze implies they will be larger in scope.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes a non-frustrating, frictionless, and easy platformer would be massively popular, citing Mario Odyssey as an example. This philosophy appears to be a guiding principle for the project.
context_findings.quote: I have this theory that games are just so goddamn bad that if you make a game that is just not offensive to the player, just like an inoffensive easy platformer with no frustration, no friction, just like easily solvable everything, people will fucking love it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze acknowledged a history of conflict with another modder, Skalox, indicating that navigating interpersonal drama is a part of the modding community landscape.
context_findings.quote: I think it is best if me and Skalox just do not acknowledge each other's existence anymore. I think we both fare off better like that.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is acutely aware of the legal risks from Nintendo and affirmed the project must be released for free.
context_findings.quote: I cannot monetize this. I have to release it for free or I will get murdered.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expressed significant frustration with the logistics of paying his collaborator Biobak, citing issues with PayPal and the complications of using cryptocurrency for payments and taxes.
context_findings.quote: I still need to buy fucking crypto pay crypto fees just to pay Biobak and then he has to pay crypto fees too and I can't properly do this like away from my taxes.

context_findings.summary: Kaze became intensely frustrated with repeated, unsolicited technical advice from his chat, particularly regarding the Parallel Launcher emulator which does not work on his setup.
context_findings.quote: Dude, Parallel launcher tarts can't just let me not use parallel launcher in peace... I'm just gonna become the number one parallel launcher hater. Just because you guys keep telling me to use it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze praised new Chinese regulations against predatory monetization in video games like daily login rewards and certain gacha mechanics, stating that China "recently saved video gaming."
context_findings.quote: They are banning a bunch of predatory techniques in China. So if you wanna make a video game that is gonna be published in China, you will have to adhere to a lot of things that video game companies will not enjoy.

biobak.summary: Biobak is responsible for finishing several graphical areas in the 'Oily Boily Bay' level, indicating a workflow where Kaze does initial blockouts and Biobak provides the final art polish.
biobak.quote: Biobak said he would finish this area. So this is a little unfinished right now.

biobak.summary: Kaze is facing challenges paying Biobak due to issues with PayPal, highlighting the logistical and financial complexities of managing a remote, international team on a fan project.

badub.summary: Badub is the primary composer for the project, creating the music for the Wild West level and establishing a consistent collaborative relationship with Kaze.
badub.quote: Who made the music for this level? Badub. He always makes the music for my levels. Nowadays at least.

zeina.summary: Zeina, who is also Kaze's spouse, is contributing 3D models to the project, such as a large skull asset for the Wild West level.
zeina.quote: There will be a skull here that Zeina is working on right now. So I am just going to mark it like that.

zeina.summary: Kaze's interactions with Zeina during the stream are casual and integrated, showing a seamless blend of their personal and professional collaboration.
zeina.quote: Look what you did, Zeina. They're making fun of me.

key_stories.title: The Emulator War
key_stories.summary: When repeatedly pressured by his audience to use a specific piece of software that doesn't work on his system, Kaze delivered an impassioned rant detailing his frustrating history with it. This story reveals his technical preferences, his frustration with unproductive community feedback, and the challenges of being a public-facing developer.
key_stories.challenge: Viewers in the chat repeatedly insisted that Kaze use the Parallel Launcher emulator, despite him stating it doesn't work for him.
key_stories.process: After initially ignoring the comments, Kaze paused his work to address the chat directly. He explained his long history of trying to get the emulator to work, his preferred alternatives (NEMU64, real hardware), and why Parallel Launcher is not a useful tool for his specific workflow.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze firmly established his reasons for not using the emulator, venting his frustration at the community's persistence and asking to be left alone on the topic. The incident highlighted the difficult dynamic of dealing with unsolicited and unhelpful advice while streaming.
key_stories.key_quote: The people, literally the person that programmed parallel launcher. In the discord with me. And he couldn't figure out what's wrong. Stop trying to tell me. No. You're coping.

key_stories.title: The Quest for the Perfect Pipe
key_stories.summary: To create multi-colored shortcuts for a level, Kaze undertook a multi-stage process of 3D modeling, texture work, and custom programming. The effort involved deep-level debugging to solve a mysterious crash, ultimately resulting in a versatile and polished asset that met his high standards.
key_stories.challenge: The project needed a versatile, aesthetically pleasing warp pipe model that could be used in multiple colors without creating redundant assets.
key_stories.process: Kaze created a new pipe model in Blender and iteratively worked on its texture to achieve a satisfying N64-style shine. He then wrote custom code to change the pipe's color based on a parameter, but this caused the game to crash. Using the NEMU64 emulator, he debugged the issue at the assembly level and fixed his code, finally achieving the desired result.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully created a new pipe model and a system to color it dynamically, resulting in an asset he was proud of. He also considered colorblind accessibility and solved a complex technical crash during the process.
key_stories.key_quote: Dude, these pipes look so good now what the fuck.

key_stories.title: Directing to the Beat
key_stories.summary: Kaze demonstrated his music-first design philosophy by building a level's intro cutscene around its score. He meticulously synced every camera cut to the beat of the music, iteratively tweaking the timing until it perfectly matched the rhythm, showing how audio drives the visual direction.
key_stories.challenge: The 'Oily Boily Bay' level required an introductory cutscene to establish its atmosphere.
key_stories.process: Kaze's entire design process for the cutscene was anchored to the music. He listened to the track on a loop to identify key beats, planned a sequence of camera pans and shots to match, and then implemented them using splines. He then made micro-adjustments to the timing, shifting cuts by a few frames until they felt perfectly in rhythm.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully created a short but impactful intro cutscene where the camera movements and cuts are perfectly synchronized with the level's theme music.
key_stories.key_quote: The most important part of the cutscene for me is that it's fitting to the music. So, which beat do we cut it on? That's the question.
